item.title: Asian Stocks to Fall After Fed’s Inflation Warning: Markets Wrap
item.description: Asian equities were primed to open lower Thursday after Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell said he expects inflation to pickup meaningfully in the coming months.
item.dc:creator: Richard Henderson

media:content.media:description: An electronic ticker displays figures for the Nikkei 225 Stock Average, top, and the Hang Seng Index on a footbridge in Pudong's Lujiazui Financial District in Shanghai, China, on Thursday, April 3, 2025. The US has hit China with the biggest-ever tariff hike on almost all Chinese products, bringing total levies to at least 54%, a move that could decimate Chinese shipments to the world’s largest economy.

item.title: Stocks Erase Gains as Powell Flags Inflation Risks | The Close 6/18/2025
item.description: Bloomberg Television brings you the latest news and analysis leading up to the final minutes and seconds before and after the closing bell on Wall Street. Today's guests are Ken Shinoda, Doubleline Capital, Betsy Duke, Former Fed Governor, Andrea DiCenso, Loomis, Sayles & Co, Vincent Reinhart, BNY Investments, Thomas Hoenig, Former Kansas City Fed President, Scott Chronert, Citi. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Billionaire Dai to Reap $237 Million Windfall From Qualcomm Deal
item.description: Weili Dai has built a career helping turn tech startup after tech startup into successful ventures. The serial entrepreneur is now poised to pocket a windfall from one of them: $237 million from the pending sale of Alphawave IP Group Plc to Qualcomm Inc.
item.dc:creator: Filipe Pacheco, Pui Gwen Yeung

item.title: How David Blitzer Invests Across Sports Leagues
item.description: Alex Rodriguez and Jason Kelly sit with David Blitzer, co-founder of Harris Blitzer Sports & Entertainment, to discuss how his teams use data and analytics to improve the fan experience. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: China’s Top Soy Sauce Maker Set to Begin Trading in Hong Kong
item.description: Foshan Haitian Flavouring & Food Co., China’s biggest soy sauce maker, will begin trading in Hong Kong on Thursday after its HK$10.1 billion ($1.3 billion) stock offering drew strong demand from investors.
item.dc:creator: Charlie Zhu, Kelly Li

media:content.media:description: Foshan Haitian soy sauce. Source: CFOTO/Future Publishing/Getty Images

item.title: Foreign Treasuries Holdings Held Near a Record in April Turmoil
item.description: Foreign investors’ holdings of US Treasuries held close to a record high in April, despite the turmoil in financial markets in the wake of President Donald Trump’s plans for the biggest tariff hikes in more than a century.
item.dc:creator: Chris Anstey, Ye Xie

media:content.media:description: The US Treasury building in Washington, DC, US, on Tuesday, June 17, 2025. The US Treasury has $144 billion of extraordinary measures left, in addition to its cash pile, to help keep paying the government's bills, the department said, citing data as of June 11.

item.title: Fmr. Fed President on Today's Interest Rate Decision
item.description: Thomas Hoenig, Former Kansas City Fed President speaks with Alix Steel and Romaine Bostick about Fed Day and Powell's press conference. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Dot Plot Was More Dovish Than Expected: BNY Economist
item.description: Vincent Reinhart, BNY Investments, Chief Economist speaks with Alix Steel and Romaine Bostick about Fed Day and inflation forecasts. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Trump to Meet Team on Israel-Iran Clash, Undecided on US Strike
item.description: President Donald Trump said he would hold another meeting Wednesday to discuss the conflict in the Middle East but remained coy about whether the US plans to join Israel’s offensive aimed at destroying Iran’s nuclear enrichment program. Trump told reporters he would meet his advisers in the White House Situation Room and again chastised Tehran for being “late” to negotiate with him, but said he had not made a final decision on whether to launch strikes. “I have ideas as to what to do,” the president told reporters in the Oval Office. “I like to make the final decision one second before it’s due because things change, especially with war.” (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Petrobras Strives to Pay Extra Dividends Brazil Needs for Budget
item.description: State-controlled oil producer Petrobras is making an effort to pay extraordinary dividends that the government is counting on this year to shore up public finances.
item.dc:creator: Mariana Durao

media:content.media:description: Magda Chambriard speaks during a press conference at the company headquarters in Rio de Janeiro on June 18.

item.title: Stocks Erase Gains as Powell Flags Inflation Risks: Markets Wrap
item.description: A rally in stocks fizzled out after Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell warned that tariff-driven economic uncertainty and inflation risk continued to complicate the central bank’s bid to ease monetary policy in earnest. Gains in bonds waned. The dollar barely budged.
item.dc:creator: Rita Nazareth

item.title: Former Fed Governor on the Central Bank's Path Forward
item.description: Betsy Duke, Former Fed Governor speaks with Alix Steel and Romaine Bostick about Fed Day and Powell's press conference. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Somalia Sets Up Its First Exchange to Trade Stocks, Sukuk Bonds
item.description: Somalia will begin trading equities and government-issued sukuk bonds on a new exchange early next year, as the Horn of Africa nation seeks integration into regional and global financial markets.
item.dc:creator: Eric Ombok

media:content.media:description: The Mogadishu skyline in Somalia in 2022.

item.title: Bridging Finance Executives Receive Fines, Bans in Ontario Fraud Case
item.description: David and Natasha Sharpe, the husband-and-wife team found to have committed fraud at private lender Bridging Finance Inc., were fined and ordered by Canada’s top securities regulator to repay more than C$20 million ($14.6 million).
item.dc:creator: Melissa Shin, Paula Sambo

item.title: Caris Life Sciences Shares Climb After $494 Million IPO
item.description: Caris Life Sciences Inc. jumped 33% after the health-care company raised $494 million in a US initial public offering that priced above the top of its marketed range.
item.dc:creator: Angel Adegbesan, Anthony Hughes

media:content.media:description: A Caris Life Sciences blood lab in Phoenix, Arizona.

item.title: US Plans Texas Facility to Stop Flesh-Eating Cattle Pest
item.description: The US Department of Agriculture announced a plan to open an $8.5 million facility in South Texas to combat the spread of the New World screwworm, a flesh-eating bug that is deadly to cattle.
item.dc:creator: Gerson Freitas Jr

media:content.media:description: CIUDAD JUAREZ, MEXICO - MAY 13: A view of the empty livestock areas at US-Mexico border in Ciudad Juarez as The United States has closed its border to live cattle imports from Mexico due to the detection of screwworms, a parasitic threat to livestock in Mexico, on May 13, 2025. The move has led to the emptying of a corral in Ciudad Juarez, a key export point for live cattle shipments to the US. The closure, announced on Tuesday, May 13, is aimed at preventing the spread of the parasite into American herds. (Photo by Christian Torres/Anadolu via Getty Images)

item.title: US Bonds Rally Stalls as Powell Endorses a Patient Fed Approach
item.description: The Treasury market stalled after Federal Reserve officials indicated they’re still on course to deliver two interest-rate reductions this year, despite the risk of resurgent inflation.
item.dc:creator: Michael Mackenzie, Ye Xie

media:content.media:description: The US Treasury building in Washington, DC. Photographer: Al Drago/Bloomberg

item.title: US Stocks Muted as Powell’s Inflation Comments Trigger Pullback
item.description: US stocks barely moved on Wednesday as Federal Reserve officials left interest rates unchanged and Chair Jerome Powell warned that meaningful inflation could come in the months ahead.
item.dc:creator: Joel Leon

media:content.media:description: Traders work on the floor at the New York Stock Exchange.

item.title: US Convertible Bonds’ Biggest Week Since 2021 Echoes Covid Boom
item.description: Convertible bonds in the US had their best week in more than four years, with surging demand enabling companies to tap the market at low prices rarely seen since the pandemic.
item.dc:creator: Yiqin Shen, Anthony Hughes

media:content.media:description: The Cloudflare headquarters in San Francisco, California, US, on Monday, April 29, 2024. Cloudflare Inc. is expected to release earnings figures on May 2. Photographer David Paul Morris/Bloomberg

item.title: Fed's Powell: Economy is in Solid Position | Closing Bell
item.description: Comprehensive cross-platform coverage of the U.S. market close on Bloomberg Television, Bloomberg Radio, and YouTube with Romaine Bostick, Alix Steel, Carol Massar and Tim Stenovec. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Fed in ‘Nothing to See Here’ Mode: BlackRock’s Rosenberg
item.description: Jeffrey Rosenberg, portfolio manager of the systematic multi-strategy fund at BlackRock, reacts to the Federal Reserve’s policy-setting Federal Open Market Committee decision to hold the benchmark federal funds rate in a range of 4.25%-4.5%.

item.title: US Senate Passes Stablecoin Bill | Bloomberg Markets 6/18/2025
item.description: "Bloomberg Markets" follows the market moves across every global asset class and discusses the biggest issues for Wall Street. Today's guests; Charles Schwab Chief Investment Strategist, Coinbase VP of US Policy Kara Calvert, Newmark President of Leasing for North America Liz Hart, Pangae Policy Founder Terry Haines, and Caris Life Sciences Founder, Chairman and Ceo David Dean Halbert. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Oil Edges Up in Turbulent Trade Amid Fears of War Escalation
item.description: Oil edged higher after a volatile session as President Donald Trump fanned speculation that the US may join the Middle East conflict.
item.dc:creator: Julia Fanzeres, Catherine Cartier

item.title: Clarida Expects 10-Year Yield Curve to Steepen
item.description: Richard Clarida, global economic adviser at Pimco and former vice chair of the Federal Reserve, discusses the outlook for bond yields after the Fed’s decision to to hold the benchmark federal funds rate in a range of 4.25%-4.5%. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Bitcoin Options Show Traders Hedging Against a Dip to $100,000
item.description: Bitcoin options show traders are hedging against a price pullback to the $100,000 price level with geopolitical and economic uncertainty lingering over global financial markets.
item.dc:creator: Sidhartha Shukla

media:content.media:description: Open Interest by strike price for put and call options on Deribit.

item.title: Pimco and King Street’s AmSurg Windfall Caps Ugly Distressed-Debt Saga
item.description: The sale of AmSurg, an ambulatory surgery company once part of KKR & Co.-backed Envision Healthcare Corp., caps an epic distressed-debt saga that will hand a windfall to investors that took ownership of the business after an ugly debt brawl.
item.dc:creator: Eliza Ronalds-Hannon

item.title: Powell Says Fed Well-Positioned to Wait to Learn More
item.description: The Federal Reserve held its benchmark interest rate in a range of 4.25%-4.5%, as they have at each of their meetings this year. Chair Jerome Powell said the US economy is in a solid position and the current stance of policy is well positioned to wait to learn more before adjusting. Powell delivered his opening statement during a press conference in Washington. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Fed’s Powell Says Tariffs Likely to Lift Prices
item.description: Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell says the size of the economic effects from tariffs are highly uncertain but monetary policy is in a good place to react. He speaks at a news conference following the Fed’s decision to to hold the benchmark federal funds rate in a range of 4.25%-4.5%.

item.title: Houston’s Electric Utility Is Prepared for Storms After 2024 Blackout, CEO Says
item.description: Houston’s electric utility is confident significant grid investments will prevent a repeat of widespread blackouts that occurred last summer following Hurricane Beryl.
item.dc:creator: Naureen S Malik, Mark Chediak

media:content.media:description: Downed power lines following Hurricane Beryl in July 2024. Photographer: Mark Felix/Bloomberg

item.title: Klarna Boosts ‘Super-App’ Ambitions With Mobile Service
item.description: Klarna CEO Sebastian Siemiatkowski discusses why the fintech startup is launching a mobile service and how the future of digital financial assistants could impact utility prices. He joins Caroline Hyde and Ed Ludlow on “Bloomberg Tech.” (Source: Bloomberg)
